newsitem.title: USA: AT&T chief calls Bill Gates tough competitor.
newsitem.headline: AT&T chief calls Bill Gates tough competitor.

text.p: AT&T Corp. Chairman Robert Allen Tuesday called Microsoft Corp. Chairman Bill Gates a tough competitor who would "do virtually anything to kill the rest of us."
In remarks to the Commonwealth Club, a current affairs forum in San Francisco, Allen said Gates was "very smart" and that "we do respect him."
But in response to a question from the audience, Allen added "one has to be very suspicious."
"I'm not a great student of Bill Gates. I take much of what he says with a grain of salt because Bill would like to be ... the centre of gravity for the whole world," Allen said.
"He's totally dedicated to his work and will do virtually anything to kill the rest of us," Allen said. "Bill Gates can be your partner and be your enemy at the same time."

Microsoft, the world's largest software maker, recently struck a deal with AT&T to be the premier browser on AT&T's WorldNet Internet service, much to the chagrin of rival Internet browser maker Netscape Communications Corp.

During his speech, Allen discussed the Internet, but focused on competition for local telephone service. He described local phone service as the "last bastion of big-time monopoly" in the U.S. communications market.
